The deployment pipelining we talk about in continuous delivery is by analogy with CPU instruction pipelining: the CPU continues to decode instructions optimistically, expecting there won’t be a branch. Analogously, we assume every change is releasable until we find a problem.

OK after quite a long and enlightening discussion with @norootcause I have now clarified that what I think of as start / end times for an incident are maybe better expressed as "start / end of potential user impact" (which is also the period I use for impact analysis)
Don’t confuse being unsure what’s going on because reality is fundamentally socially constructed with being unsure what’s going on because you have shitty monitoring.

Just a note that social constructs are real and can have measurable, objective characteristics. Money and countries are social constructs. Countries have boundaries and areas, economies, populations, all of which in turn can be modeled.

@OliDevOps @existensil Yes, core memory was woven. But first the programs that were woven into core memory had to be developed. That was actual software engineering. You can’t compare the creation of this codebase to weaving, that’s a category error. https://t.co/Qr4R5iLUQi

@OliDevOps @existensil Unlike ENIAC, Colossus wasn't a general purpose programmable computer. Women were leading the programming of computers well into the era where it was recognizably modern software engineering.

@OliDevOps @existensil You're talking about encoding the programs into core memory (the equivalent of programming an EPROM). The actual code was developed using the practice of software engineering (a term invented by Margaret Hamilton, who led the team that wrote the guidance computer software, shown) https://t.co/z9KXKhSApW

@OliDevOps @existensil You're talking about encoding the programs into core memory (the equivalent of programming an EPROM). The thing that I found most valuable - and most generally underrated - from learning TDD 5 years into my career is the art of developing by making lots of small, targeted commits that each deliver an increment but leave the codebase deployable. Multiple commits per day.

Reading Chapter 3 of The Deficit Myth where @StephanieKelton explains that the "national debt" is just the outstanding total of savings held in US Treasury bonds, and the Federal Reserve could cancel it just by pressing some keys. The idea that it's money we "owe" is misleading.

Distributed systems tip of the day: while CAP theorem prohibits 100% consistency and 100% availability in the presence of network partitions, it does permit zero consistency and zero availability.
Distributed systems architectural best practice of the day: don’t design systems that require strongly-consistent leader election

University of California lecturers will be striking tomorrow and Thursday. I'm not teaching this semester, but I'll be on the picket lines. UC lecturers teach 1/3 of credit hours, but the median wage in 2019 was $19,067. We've been offered a 3% raise when inflation is over 6%.

If you think pair programming is inefficient, try waiting hours to get your code reviewed & having to context switch between tasks while you wait. And then switch back when you get the feedback & have to rethink your approach because you weren’t discussing it as you wrote it.
@RageQuitFPS Yeah I have definitely been told off for that. I have a short attention span. It's why I don't recommend pairing full time...

The thing that I found most valuable - and most generally underrated - from learning TDD 5 years into my career is the art of developing by making lots of small, targeted commits that each deliver an increment but leave the codebase deployable. Multiple commits per day.

Everyone sensible in IT has been saying for years that if you buy COTS (commercial off-the-shelf software packages) you shouldn’t customize it - it’s wildly expensive and you end up with something hard to maintain and almost impossible to upgrade.
@collabject @johncutlefish Thank you!

We’ve known for years about the toxicity of PFAS, a class of chemicals used to make non-stick packaging, furniture, & firefighting foam: https://t.co/yptZFxjS5V.
